reviews.review_msg: Basically, all the assignments were asking you to google stuff. Barely learned anything in this class.

You need to learn many programming languages by yourself. E.g. Haskell, Scala Lots of programming homeworks. He won't teach those languages but he expect students can use those languages to implement matrix operators and use concurrent programming. For the lecture, you will have no idea what he is talking about.

He is a very nice and friendly guy. He knows his stuff, but his teaching is confusing and all over the place. He is unorganized and you will do well if you just read the textbook. His tests and assignments are not too hard.

Really nice guy, but he's a terrible professor. I was hoping for a class on Programming Languages, given the name of the course and all, but instead got a class on abstract math. I'm used to that at this point, but the fact that he was too confused to continue his lectures most of the time made it pretty hard to take. Sign up with a different prof.
Generally a good guy, but makes many many mistakes when he teaches
Super easy tests.goes on&on&off topic.quote: urhhh  often  hangs  like computers
Be prepared to master Haskell.  Not the hottest skill in the world.

Easy but fun. Toby gives an average of B+ though according to the average stats in canvas it should be B. Anyway the marking is generous. The only killer is the final (59%) but you can do well by simply memorzing all the stuff.
Learned a lot about functional programming in this course, and the prof definitely knew what he was talking about.

The class is not difficult, but the concepts learned are very engaging. To add to this, Toby has done everyone a favour by uploading a lecture recording of every class. This makes it so that you can simply stay at home, and watch the lectures videos 1.5x speed. Toby also explains concepts well. I would recommend this class to everyone in CMPT/SoSy.
Best cmpt prof ever. He provides a lot of excellent examples during lectures and provide everything you know on the course website. Exams are very fair and everything is based on his course website.
383 was an interesting class that teaches some more obscure languages but still manages to improve your overall skill in programming. Toby teaches the course well.
Very nice prof, will take his course again. The assignments are not easy but really help you to understand. Notes are online and everything are base on the notes.

IMO the best prof I've had at SFU. I've taken 135 and now 383 with him and in each of those classes I've actually learned something useful. In 383 you get really into functional programming and the languages you have to learn really teaches you to think in a different way. Very fair assignments and exams. Take this course with him.

His lectures were interesting, and his assignments were well related to the material that he taught. His midterm and final were fair, completely based on the notes for his class. Didn't use the textbook much, just read his notes on his website. If you had to take this class, take it with him!

Excellent Prof.  His online notes are awesome!  Just study those thoroughly.  His assignments are super fun.  They are like puzzles and are about the right difficulty.  Highly recommend this prof for CMPT 383!!

Great & helpful prof! Very glad to have taken 383 with him, he couldn't have explained concepts better. His midterm/final were extremely fair, if you studied you did fine - generally he will give outlines, follow them! Assignments/projects sometimes tedious but for the most part very manageable. Great course overall! Definitely recommend.
Nice guy, very easy course, but very slow. The only imperfect thing is that he never gives feedback and comments on homework.
No Comments

Very unorganized. Frequently came to class unprepared. Class average was very high up until the final exam. Did not follow his initial schedule. Assignments were not graded in a timely fashion. Good personality but bad lecturing skills!!!
Easy contents but hard exams.

Decent prof, but the assignments were *ABSOLUTELY* brutal, and very little related to the course topics. Also, the midterm was extremely challenging. Quite tricky final, too. He ended up scaling the grades, though, which was very fair in my opinion, because of the low class average. Briefly put: decent prof, super boring course.

His exercise and exams are closely related to his lecture and notes. And he presents his ideas well. Just one thing, textbooks is useless in his class, all you need to do is to follow his ideas in the class. Sometimes its a bit confusing for me.

He taught 383 very well.  Well spoken and laid back, grades fairly and created interesting and relevant assignments.  Exams are well-written and are directly related to course material.  Terrific for what I believe is his first time teaching the class.

Really good professor and he knows his stuff really well. The class homework and assignemnts are not hard. The final was very fair and you can do well if you can understand the homework. The midterm was a little challenging. The course is very interesting and Professor Wang is really good. Highly recommend.

Haskell changed my life. 
Before: miserable, sad, depressed. After: enlightenment, free from the cycles of suffering.
He (in my opinion) has a very deep understanding of functional programming/Haskell and really cares about communicating abstract topics in ways that are easier to understand.
Who wouldda thought that abstract topics are abstract.

Dr. Wang is a very good professor. He understands the course material and he can explain it clearly. He is very willing to help if you have questions on your assignments. You should expect a relatively heavy workload in this course. The material is kind of abstract. Don't take it if you don't have a solid background.
Informative notes. Timely responses. Always ready to provide feedbacks and help people. Great professor that you don't want to miss at SFU!

This is a challenging course with tons of assignments and hard quizzes, but if you survive you will get a lot out of it. Unlike the other sessions (which are basically functional programming bootcamps), Professor Wang diverts to covering abstract topics in the latter half of the course, such as Semantics Verification. Overall, great experience!

Unlike previous 383 classes, this class with Yuepeng is purely Haskell. The lectures are very abstract and hard to follow, there is weekly homework, as well as extremely difficult programming assignments. Quizzes were very unreasonable, both had a failing average. Overall, Yuepeng is nice and is trying to improve. He takes class feedback seriously

Haskell only. Very reasonable individual assignments that only require concepts from the slides/lectures. Lots of homework assignments, but each one can be finished quickly. Can skip class and just read slides for all information. Does not answer Piazza questions well.

A poorly structured course, and poorly taught. Cameron's interest in the subject seemed very low, and assumed that students had so much prior knowledge. Assignments were VERY difficult and demanding, and lectures were uninformative and boring. Overall: He expects  lot, but offers very little help to students.
Really hard marker...hard to understand. Instructions for assignments are unclear.

CMPT 384 - 

One of the worst professors at SFU. Homework is so hard and does not give partial marks in Exams. He does not know how to teach. Expects you to know everything. More than half the class dropped. Only 50 students were left at end.

People keep saying that homework/assignments were just "practice" but fail to realize that if everyone does similarly on the homework/assignments, then the only thing differentiating them is their exam performance. The exams weren't even that unfair for a 3rd year course, (reverse a linked list/check code will compile).
Nice prof, but the course is graded very harshly.

I want to say I liked Anders. He was funny and nice and I liked his assignments, but the final grade distribution was so egregious that it ruined the otherwise not so bad class/teaching style and I can't give him more than a 2.

Anders is a cheerful and competent lecturer. He is approachable after class, willing to answer questions, and has strong interest and knowledge in his field. Attending class is very helpful, if you miss any lectures, reading the provided material is a good alternative. The exam was quite challenging, but partial marks were given and curved.

I took CMPT 383 the first time it was taught by Anders and it was lovely; he has new photos of his pet at the beginning of every lecture, and the assignments are fun, despite that the content gets tricky in the first half. If you email him you'll get back thoughtful responses.

If you enjoy programming, you'll love this course and this prof.

Grade is mostly based on the exams even though 60% is on assignments. Very strict grading on exams w/ no partial grades. For example, either you get 0, 5, or 10 out of 10 for a question. You will get penalized for incorrect answers, so make sure to BOX the CORRECT answers. C- to B+ was spread across 70-77% w/ 150 students in the class. C+ average.

First midterm had 3 mistakes and he gave us no extra time, we wasted time reading wrong questions. Teaches horribly, you have to go through the attached readings yourself to learn. Following the slides is very confusing, this guy has never put any ounce of information together without making mistakes in them. Yet if YOU make a mistake, then C-

This was a very stressful course to take. The exams were insanely difficult for both midterms (had 3 typos too). He expects you to be as good as him in coding Haskell and Rust when you've only had 1 and a half months learning each language. He himself is extremely disorganized and has said "I'm too lazy" literally in every class about 5 times.

Fall 2024, he announced this class is no longer GPA booster. The end of the semester, the average is C+, he delivered his promise. Vitamins and Assignments are technically just for practice, he gave out letter grade based on your exam only. His new grade scaling seems ridiculous: B-: 73.99-72.5, C+: 72.49-72, C: 71.99-70.1, C-: 70.09-64.

Anders can be disorganized in his teachings. The lecture slides are riddled with typos and his explanations are hard to follow due to the his pacing. The midterms are tricky and difficult which is worsened by his deceiving methods of giving partial credit. Overall, Anders is an enthusiastic person who falls short as a student-centered lecturer.

Weekly homework and assignments were easy but solely based on conceptual problems. The 2 midterms were ATROCIOUS and lowered everyone's grades (the avg was around a 40% for both). On top of that, he had custom grade cutoffs in which a 70% was a C. It seemed like he was hell-bent on breaking the notion of this class being a GPA booster in the past.

Not bad at teaching, pretty enthusiastic guy. But the exams were very difficult, part marks were hard to earn, the averages were in the 40s. Don't believe his initial grading scheme as most of the class got scaled down 1 to 2 letter grades.

Anders is probably my favorite CMPT professor at SFU. He goes above and beyond to ensure that students understand material, and his lectures are clear and easy to follow. He makes complicated topics seem easy. And he answers emails incredibly quickly. And he's very generous with regrading exams if you have any grading objections. 100% recommend

Agree with the passionate part. Assignments / Weekly programming exercises are fair (some might say a breeze?) Would have appreciated more challenging ones. Doesn't go too deeply into the languages and their features. Course materials heavily rely on the official docs, and are by no means in depth. Exams are A-OK.
Great prof! Passionate about his work and you will learn a lot

Anders was an extremely enthusiastic professor and that showed in his teaching. He was able to use this enthusiasm to teach us quite well. He has clear grading criteria and reasonable weekly small assignments, as well a few big ones. Midterm was a bit difficult, but no final. Just two midterms.

Greg is one of the best profs I've had at SFU. Some ppl say he's “rude,” but I'd call it blunt. He's direct and doesn't waste words. The course had 15% weekly exercises, 3 longer/harder assignments 35%, and exams worth 50%. Homework was easy marks if you kept up, assignments took ~20 hrs, and exams were tough, but fair. I'd recommend Greg any day.

As a lecturer, Greg is pretty good at delivering engaging lectures. He is clearly knowledgable, and even likes to crack a joke every once and a while. Outside of lectures, he was helpful, although I felt he could come across as a bit of a jerk sometimes. Felt like he had a bit of a superiority complex and isn't interested in your side of the story.

Good prof. People complaining he's rude are just not used to being treated like adults. He's not gonna waste your time and expects you to know your stuff from the prereqs. You're dipping into two new languages, be ready and willing to research on your own. Assignments, exercises, exams are fair. No quizzes.

Extremely difficult course content but that's how the course is, not Greg's fault. He was enthusiastic about the content throughout the course. All lectures were delivered on YouTube so no attendance was needed. Really weird slide formatting. Be aware that there are weekly exercises and exams make up 50% of the grade so tons of pressure.
His teaching in lecture is far from the worst. But interactions in email or office hours is just a pain. It seems like he's only there because the school makes him.

He has a very poor attitude towards students, and he doesn't care about the results of students' projects. You can't feel the slightest respect from him, especially if you want to discuss anything with him or ask questions, because you take up his "extremely precious" time.

He teaches well, but he is extremely rude and disrespectful towards students. I am too scared to ask him any questions. If he could change his behavior towards students, that would make a big difference.

Lectures are good quality. Weekly exercises that are short but good refreshers of material. Assignments have clear and unambiguous descriptions (this is rare) and are very related to course material. Tests required some coding, so you have to be familiar with the languages. If you do the assignments and exercise you will be fine.

His teaching style, workload, and exams are fair. If you do the work, you can pass the class. The only thing I wish he would change is his attitude toward responding to students' questions. In Piazza, he sometimes responds with one-word replies or a question. In a learning environment, this way of response is discouraging for students.

Exposure to functional programming and other niche programming languages. Although greg baker was a solid lecturer, the course was not all that memorable as most of the assignments were dull and haskell (which greg focuses on in this course) is likely a language you will never use again.

He also tries to keep the course material as relevant as possible to the current time. He understands the student mentality so he will try to make the course enjoyable and sometimes cancels lectures because "Monday sucks"

Greg is awesome. He puts a lot of effort into his class notes and assignments, and it shows. He is really knowledgeable (although he likes to go on one too many rants). I learned a lot from this class, and it is great that the professor is very passionate.

Greg is a very chill guy who explains all concepts clearly and thoroughly. Weekly exercises really ensure that you have a good understanding of the languages learned (Haskell and Go). Midterms and final were very fair with no surprises, and were mostly coding based. I will definitely try to take another class with Greg if I can!
The assignments are super unclear, but he is an amazing instructor which teaches you a lot. If he could improve the assignments documentation, definitely deserve A+ for teaching ability.

He is straight, to-the-point, and rather blunt. He gets impatient and irritated if you don't appear to be "getting it" quickly enough, though. Exams contain extrapolations of the class material, not just straightforward regurgitation; study BEYOND what has been covered in class.
It is a tough course with weekly assignments, but I wouldn't take it with anyone else!

3 main parts to the course. Haskell, Language features, then Prolog. Haskell and language features consist of many lectures, while prolog gets two. On the final, haskell is a large portion, language features is not represented enough, and prolog is represented too much. Averages are high so be prepared for scaling, as in an 86% will not give an A.

He is a very gifted lecturer. His courses are planned out in a smart manner. He gives relevant weekly exercises for you to practice the material and get your feet wet in preparation for big assignments. His exams are fair, although a bit coding heavy. He uses overhead, which keeps the pace nice. You get the feeling that he puts more into lectures.

Let's be honest: Wikipedia articles are often the best introductory descriptions to concepts you'll find anywhere. This is what he said for his a lot of links. And I want to say that I didn't pay my tuition fee for the bunch of Wikipedia links. His teaching skill is okay, but he doesn't have a good manner when you ask something through email.
boring, feels like reading a book and not helpful at all.

The class can be challenging but Greg is definitely one of the more engaging professors you will ever see at SFU. Highly recommend any class he is teaching.  I have taken 3 of his classes if not more.

One of few profs who still teach using an overhead, which is GOOD because it keeps the pace manageable. Learned two new prog langs, a new paradigm, and got more prolog practice from this course: well worth it. Weekly exercises and three fairly large assignments. Not too tough if you start early. Tests are programming heavy so be sure to practice!
one of the best prof. explains everything really well. you will really learn a lot from this prof. Assignments exams were reasonable.
Course material is valuable to all programmers, and Greg teaches it extremely well. The weekly exercises and assignments relate to the course notes, so you rarely feel lost. Highly recommended!

Haven't taken too many CMPT courses yet, but this was excellent. Lectures are at a pace that's really digestable and interesting. Assignments are very manageable once you start working on them. He's super friendly and gets to the point with what he's teaching. Exams are very fair; just review the notes and do all the exercises on paper for practice

Both an excellent professor and topic. Lecture notes help you finish exercises which give you sufficient practice to find concepts intuitive. An easy course if you do your work, yet it teaches important topics. Greg is knowledgeable, apt and honest. He demonstrates concepts in class and knows industry trends. Very fun and informative class.

best class ever! weekly exercises give you practise. lecture material and exam/assignment material have high correlation. all required programming were fun and interesting. learned a lot about what's out there in the programming world, truly eye opening course. if you do your exers and asn, exams need not be prepared for

Never take this course if you are not an expert in programming, there is no so much help, most of emails are no replying by TAs or prof, material are brutal hard and vague, every week you have exercises.Also you have 3 assignments each one with a weird language which even one of them even did teach. Prof speaks super fast. never take it.
Great prof, clear lectures, interested in material, useful/interesting assignments.

He is the best lecturer I have met. You can benefit a lot from his interesting lectures. His weekly exercises are pretty helpful to understand materials. If you devote yourself into his notes and exercises during the term, you may spend very little time reviewing before the final. (I only spent 4 hours.) Do not hesitate to take his course!!!
Excellent course. Excellent prof. The assignments were interesting and fun. The exams were fair. He is a good lecturer. Classes are easy to follow and the energy level is high.

One of the best teachers in the CS department.  Greg is actually motivated and interested in the subject and in his students. He is charismatic and organized.  His semi-weekly labs really help you learn the material, and his assignments are actually interesting. In addition, he does them first, so you know you can get the help you need. Recommended
